awd_titl_txt: Monitoring and Optimization in Coupled Natural Gas and Electric Power Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The pressing need for efficient, low-carbon, and fast-responding electric power generators and decreasing prices of natural gas are currently transforming natural gas networks. The intermittent operation of gas-fired power plants to compensate wind generation introduces spatiotemporal fluctuations in continuously increasing volumes of gas demand. Generation and network contingencies in power transmission systems can affect shortages in gas supplies; and vice versa, congested and suboptimally scheduled gas networks limit the integration of renewable energy. In this context, this project studies the interdependency between these two critical infrastructures through coordinated control and market operations to ensure stability, reliability, and efficiency. The research project will develop algorithmic tools for the analysis, optimization, and monitoring of natural gas networks and their interplay with electric power grids. The vision is threefold: develop a reliable computational toolbox for enhanced gas network operations leveraging advances in convex optimization; identify analogies, key differences, and opportunities by jointly dispatching the two energy systems; and engage data analytics for transforming both gas transmission and distribution networks into smarter cyber-physical infrastructures. The consequent gains in efficiency and awareness will be reflected on a wide gamut of industrial, commercial, and residential uses of natural gas; while enabling a smooth transition to the low-emission economy. Broader transformative impact will result from an educational dissemination plan, involvement of undergraduates in research, and outreach to the local community and high school students.

At the heart of modeling, control, and monitoring of gas networks is a set of nonlinear equations relating nodal gas injections and pressures to flows over pipelines. Building on convex relaxations, the gas flow problem is formulated as a semidefinite program that outperforms existing alternatives in terms of region of convergence and which naturally leads to coupled gas and power flow formulations. The novel scheme is generalized for optimally dispatching natural gas networks, independently or in tandem with electric power systems. To cope with uncertainty on renewable generation, and adjusting to the slower gas transients, static and dynamic setups are considered via decentralized and stochastic implementations. Efficient modules are additionally devised for enhancing situational awareness via gas network state estimation. By developing a suite of gas pressure and injection data analytics, computational efforts will aim towards enhancing local gas utility distribution networks, thus resonating with efforts for smart cities and connected communities. The utility of the proposed research goes well beyond the envisioned application area to the broader fields of stochastic optimization, statistical signal processing, control of coupled networks, inference over graphs, and dynamic modeling of fluids.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
Decreasing gas prices and the pressing need for efficient, low-carbon, and fast-responding electric power generators are currently transforming natural gas networks. The intermittent operation of gas-fired plants to compensate for wind energy introduces spatiotemporal fluctuations in continuously increasing volumes of gas demand. The interdependency between these two critical infrastructures calls for coordinated control and market operations to ensure efficiency. In this context, this project has achieved three major research goals:

G1) Develop a computational toolbox for enhanced gas network operations;

G2) Identify analogies, key differences, and opportunities by comparing energy systems; and

G3) Use data analytics to expedite the solutions of optimal scheduling problems occuring in energy system operations.

The particular outcomes supporting the aforesaid goals are outlined below. 

 

Drawing analogies between infrastructure networks. Commencing with G2), besides the electric-gas coupling, another interesting example of coupled infrastructures is the inter-dependent operation of electric power and water distribution networks. With dynamic electricity pricing, the operation of water distribution systems (WDS) is expected to become more variable. The pumps moving water from reservoirs to tanks and consumers can serve as energy storage alternatives if properly operated. Similar to natural gas networks, the hydraulic law, for which the pressure along a pipe drops proportionally to its squared water flow, challenges the optimal scheduling of WDS. We identified a neat analogue between the equations governing natural gas networks, and the equations modeling WDS. Spurred by the analogy between natural gas networks and water distribution systems, we were able to transfer results from scheduling gas to water systems as detailed below. 

 

Efficient gas flow and water flow solvers. Regarding G1), at the heart of modeling, monitoring, and control of gas networks is a set of nonlinear equations relating nodal gas injections and pressures to flows over pipelines. Given gas demands at all points of the network, the gas flow (GF) task aims at finding the rest of the physical quantities involved. For a tree-like network, the problem enjoys a closed-form solution; yet solving the equations for practical meshed networks is non-trivial. One of our objectives has been to devise efficient GF and water flow (WF) solvers with convergence and optimality guarantees. This line of research treats the GF/WF equations in a unified fashion. We devised three algorithmic GF/WF approaches of complementary strengths. The first method poses the GF/WF task as a mixed-integer second-order cone program (MI-SOCP), where binary variables capture the flow directions in pipes. The non-convex pressure drop equations are relaxed to second-order cone constraints. Upon minimizing a judiciously designed objective, the relaxation is provably exact under some network conditions. To overcome the computational complexity of MI-SOCP, our second approach solves the GF/WF task by minimizing a convex function over the linear equality constraints capturing mass conservation at each node. Pipeline flows are obtained as primal variables, and nodal pressures as the Lagrange multipliers associated with the equality constraints. As a third alternative, we adopted the energy function approach to pose the GF/WF tasks as unconstrained convex minimization problems with nodal pressures as the optimization variables. The second and third solvers succeed in solving the GF/WF tasks as long as compressors for the GF task (pumps for the WF task, respectively) do not form loops; otherwise, the first MI-SOCP solver could be used. 

 

Optimal scheduling of water distribution systems. We have also formulated the optimal water flow (OWF) task as a mixed-integer non-convex problem incorporating flow and pressure constraints, critical for the operation of fixed-speed pumps, tanks, reservoirs, and pipes. The hydraulic constraints of the OWF problem are subsequently relaxed to second-order cone constraints, and a penalty term is appended to its objective to promote solutions feasible for the water network. The modified problem can be solved as a mixed-integer second-order cone program, which is analytically shown to yield WDS-feasible minimizers under certain sufficient conditions. By weighting the penalty in the objective of the relaxed problem, its minimizers can attain arbitrarily small optimality gaps, thus providing OWF solutions.

 

Optimization data analytics. To expedite the solution of the optimization problems involved in optimal resource allocation in energy systems and infrastructure networks, one novel idea has been to train a learning model that learns to predict the solutions of the optimization problem. We explored this idea within the concept of optimal power flow problems and achieved improved data efficiency and significant speedups in computations.

 

Concerning broader impacts, research results have been presented at six (6) conference venues as well as in private to several engineers and researchers from the natural gas industry industry, federal labs, and academia. The project has involved extensive training and mentoring activities on optimization, learning, and natural gas modeling, and have led to two MSc and one PhD theses. The PI has been participating to at least 2-3 outreach events annually to undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 09/10/2021
Modified by: Vassilis Kekatos

Decreasing gas prices and the pressing need for efficient, low-carbon, and fast-responding electric power generators are currently transforming natural gas networks. The intermittent operation of gas-fired plants to compensate for wind energy introduces spatiotemporal fluctuations in continuously increasing volumes of gas demand. The interdependency between these two critical infrastructures calls for coordinated control and market operations to ensure efficiency. In this context, this project has achieved three major research goals:
G1) Develop a computational toolbox for enhanced gas network operations;
G2) Identify analogies, key differences, and opportunities by comparing energy systems; and 
G3) Use data analytics to expedite the solutions of optimal scheduling problems occuring in energy system operations.

Commencing with G2), besides the electric-gas coupling, another interesting example of coupled infrastructures is the inter-dependent operation of electric power and water distribution networks. We explored this idea within the concept of optimal power flow problems and achieved improved data efficiency and significant speedups in computations.
 
Concerning broader impacts, research results have been presented at six (6) conference venues as well as in private to several engineers and researchers from the natural gas industry industry, federal labs, and academia. The project has involved extensive training and mentoring activities on optimization, learning, and natural gas modeling, and have led to two MSc and one PhD theses. The PI has been participating to at least 2-3 outreach events annually to undergraduate students.
